Post Text: Marketers, we've been living in a fantasy.  We've worshipped at the altar of the funnel:  A neat, tidy, color-coded pathway from awareness to purchase.  But let's face reality:  The consumer journey? It's not a sleek funnel.  It's a wild, tangled, unpredictable scribble.  That's how consumers ACTUALLY behave.  They don’t just glide smoothly down our funnels.  They loop back, take detours, and sometimes jump out entirely.  Sounds chaotic? Because it is.  But you're probably not ready to accept that.  You want the security of a funnel. The illusion of control.  Here's your reality check:  1. Your neat marketing funnel is too simplistic. 2. Your strategies need to account for real human behavior. 3. YOU need to navigate the complexity, not shy away from it.  The customer journey is a labyrinth. Post Text: One cold email can make you stupid money. But 99% of salespeople don't know how to write a great one. Here are the top 5 cold email tips to improve your reply rates:   1. The most important part of the email:   It's not the subject line. It's not the body.   ↳It's the name it's coming from.   If my grandma emails me I am sure as hell opening it regardless of the subject line  But....  2. Great subject lines get you up to bat more often.  STRONG subject line + MEDICORE copy  ↳is better than WEAK subject line + STRONG copy  3. People buy the benefits.   A feature is what something *is*.   A benefit is what something *does for you*.  You’ve got to understand the difference when:   → Selling → Writing → Creating Content  Features don’t make people buy.   The benefits of those features gets them to buy.  4. There are only a few parts to a great email.   • Subject line.  • Shocking statement.  • 3 or 4 bullets.  • OFFER (and dear god don't ask for 30 min)  The name on the email is still the most important though ;)   5. Post Text: In 2015 I joined a startup doing $500k in ARR.   7 years later that same startup was doing $250M+ in ARR.  Here are the 7 valuable lessons I learned that are worth your time:   𝟭// 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗼𝗳𝘁𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗮 𝘀𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗲𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗮𝗻 𝗼𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗼𝗻.  So have a conviction about the problem that your product solves.  The internet (and potential customers) reward conviction.  So put your stake in the ground:  • The problem • How your product solves the problem • Why your business is the best at solving the problem  And get crazy about honing in on this every day.   𝟮 // 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗯𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗮 𝗰𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗥𝗢𝗜.  This will help you get through tough climates like today.  When businesses cut spending the first products they cut are "nice-to-haves".  Don't wait until your customer is wanting to churn to prove ROI.  Do it early.  Do it often.  Don't be the "nice-to-have".  𝟯// 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮𝗻 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.  Be okay with that.  Treat every day like an experiment.  Try things out. See what works and what doesn't.  Make course corrections along the way.  𝟰 // 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗮 𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗮, 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴.  You need to build a great team.  The best startups are not about a great idea, they are about great recruiting.  Find and hire the best people you can.  They will be your secret weapon.  𝟱// 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘄𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗴𝗲.  They only care if you can get sh*t done.  I sat through 100s of interviews.  Not once did I care about if someone went to Harvard or not.  𝟲// 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 #𝟭 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘂𝗲.  Don't get it twisted y'all.  So many SaaS buzzword metrics out there.  There's 1 thing that should always go up and to the right...  REVENUE.  Companies don't run on email opens and clicks.  𝟳// 𝗔𝘃𝗼𝗶𝗱 "𝗕𝘂𝗧 𝗪𝗲'𝗩𝗲 𝗔𝗹𝗪𝗮𝗬𝘀 𝗗𝗼𝗡𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗧𝗵𝗜𝘀 𝗪𝗮𝗬"  This is the company killer.  You need to have the conviction to do things differently.  The only way a small company can win is by being scrappy and nimble.  By doing things differently.  Don't get caught in the trap of doing things "just because".  Do them because they make sense and will help you grow.    So there you have it.  If you're working on a startup, keep these 7 lessons in mind:  1. Your business is a piece of software with an opinion. 2. Your business needs to have a clear ROI. 3. Treat everything like an experiment. 4. Startups are not about a great idea, they are about great recruiting. 5. No one cares where you went to college. 6. Your #1 metric is revenue. 7. Avoid "BuT We'Ve AlWaYs DoNe It ThIs WaY"  What am I missing?

Post Text: Over a 24-month period at a startup, I closed $5.5 million in ARR.   Want to know a secret?   I used the same 5-step negotiation framework every time.   𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭: 𝗞𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝟯-𝟱 𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗹𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀  These can be based on:  • Volume  • When the deal closes • Length of the deal (e.g. 2-year deal vs. 3-year deal) • When you get paid (Net 30, 60, 90)  I use a slide to present these items.   Give them options (besides discount)   𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟮: 𝗨𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗺  Throughout the deal process, gather information from them that you can use in negotiations later.  Example: “My VP really cares about adoption”  In this case, you can make a price adjustment on professional services around adoption.   𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟯: 𝗨𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝟭 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹  Too often we see reps trying to finish a negotiation in 1 call.  This tends to lead to reps negotiating with themselves.  Don’t give anything away without getting something in return.   𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟰: 𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗲𝘅𝗲𝗰𝘂𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀  Executives would prefer negotiating with other executives.  Leverage other executives in a negotiation when possible.  Before adding them to a negotiation call, brief them.   𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟱: 𝗙𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆, 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱...  1. Get all negotiation items out (steps 1-4 above)   2. Repeat/Ask what you heard. "So if I got it right you want ____ Is there anything else?"  3.  Prioritize the issues. "Let me ask, what is most important to you price or..."  4. Qualify the decision maker. If we come to an agreement today can you make the decision by (today)?  5.  Make the offer. Be clear, confident, and concise.  6.  Listen and repeat their counter-offer.  7.  Ask for the deal and add an expiration date.  8.  Agree to consequences if the expiration date is not met.  9. Confirm your conversation with an email:  "Per our conversation, we agreed to ____ did I get that right?"  10. Once they've agreed in writing follow up with contract: "As discussed in the email in which we agreed to"   𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗶𝘁!   My 5-step Negotiation Framework.  Two final thoughts:   • Don’t rush the process, you’ll end up negotiating against yourself • Understand your negotiation levers ahead of time   P.S. Post Text: In December 2015 I joined a startup at $500K in ARR.   7 years later, I had written 1000s of email sequences for over 350+ companies.  Want to know a secret?   I use the same 5 sequences every time.   𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 #𝟭: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝘂𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲  Buyers aren't always ready to BUY.   When they are, you want to be top of mind.   All nurture sequences have the same format:   • 30 day nurture email • 60 day nurture email • 90 day nurture email • continued...  I each email provide VALUE.   𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 #𝟮: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗯𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲  These people don't know who you are.   Here's how to get a reply:   • Use humor • Keep it short & sweet • Teach them something new • Name drop mutual connection   𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 #𝟯: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗻𝗼 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝘀𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲  Did your prospect not show up to initial meeting?   You don't want to throw this meeting away.   • They may still be interested • They might have forgot • Timing might be off  You've already got a small "yes".  Seize it!   𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 #𝟰: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘀𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲  You connect with the wrong person 99% of the time?   Ask them:   “Who should I be reaching out to?”  Most of the time they'll tell you.   Put that person in a referral sequence.   High output sequence for very little effort!   𝗦𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 #𝟱: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹-𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝘀𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲  Can't find email and/or LinkedIn profile?   Use this sequence.   Especially when:   • Company doesn't have standard naming conventions • Person has hyphenated last name • Person has multiple nick names  They may no longer be at the company. Author: Andrew Mewborn
Post Text: 99% of salespeople make the same cold email mistake. They have first sentences that send prospects straight to SNOOZEVILLE. Save your response rate and avoid these 5 first lines:    𝟭. “𝗜 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗳𝗼𝗿 ... ”  It's boring, unoriginal, and screams to the prospect, "I'm trying to sell you something!"  Instead:  Weave your company’s name in naturally.  Like this: "X recommended we get in touch. I work with X on Google's marketing team.   𝟮. “𝗗𝗶𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄 … ?”  You can use stats to create urgency, but dropping them in randomly won't work.   If you start with a stat, make sure to personalize it to the prospect's unique situation:  • "In the past year, I helped 10 companies increase meetings booked by 10x..."   𝟯. “𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘁𝘀 𝗼𝗻 … ”  These openings are a lazy first line.   Unless... You get really specific.   🚫: “Congratulations on getting funded,”  ✅ “Just read that you raised $5 million in Series A funding from Google -- congratulations! Your plans for expansion to the east coast..."   𝟰. "𝗜 𝗵𝗼𝗽𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘄𝗲𝗹𝗹 ... "  Being vanilla kills sales.   Instead, get to the point of your message.   🚫: "I hope you're doing well..."  ✅: "I worry about your company's [ability to do X, strategy for Y, response to Z]"   𝟱. “𝗠𝘆 𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 … ”  Your prospect is asleep already. BORING!  Prospects can easily determine your name...   ...The "From" field or email signature tells them.  Fixing this error is dead simple.   Cut this sentence so your message starts with the next.   And that's it!  Avoid these first sentences:   • “I work for … ” • “Did you know … ?” • “Congrats on … ” • "I hope you're doing well ... " • “My name is … ”   What am I missing?    ***   P.S. The waitlist for our 4,000+ member LinkedIn Growth Accelerator is now open: https://www.brand30.io/

Post Text: Want to supercharge your sales career?  Learn to write better.  6 little tricks to improve your email writing:   1. Use short words. Short sentences. And, short paragraphs. Like this bullet.  2. Cut the jargon words. Your goal is to be understood, not to sound like the smartest person in the room.  3. Read your work aloud. Very underrated. Thank me later.  4. Spend more time focusing on your subject line. Take 3 minutes and write 20 versions. Pick the best one. Start there.  5. Reduce friction in your writing.  • in order to → to • facilitates → helps • whether or not → whether • due to the fact that → because  6. Ban unnecessary words.  • really • literally • actually • certainly • probably • basically  7. Get to the point. Tell the reader exactly where they are going.  Business writing, simplified:  • Avoid jargon • Reduce friction • Get to the point • Use short words • Read your work aloud • Create a banned words list • Spend more time on your "hook"  What am I missing?  ***  P.S. Author: Andrew Mewborn
Post Text: In 2019 I was throwing stuff at the wall hoping it sticks. Then, between 2020 and 2022 I closed $5.5M in revenue. Want to know a secret? I used the same 6 plays for every deal:   𝟭/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝟱𝘅𝟱 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  Pick 5 accounts.  Pick 5 people from each account.   You know have 25 prospects.   Add them all to a prospecting sequence.   Repeat this 1x/week.   𝟮/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 $𝟭𝟬𝗸 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗵𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  The average B2B deal now has 5.4 decision-makers.  Rule of thumb:   For every $10k of ARR, set a goal of 1 additional stakeholder you need to WOW  • 10k deal = 1 stakeholder to WOW • 20k deal = 2 stakeholders • 100k deal = 10 stakeholders   𝟯/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝟯-𝘀𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝗣𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  Most of us say what we need to say.  Then keep talking.  No Bueno.   Instead:   1. Say what you need to say 2. Think about pausing for 3 seconds 3. (hit the MUTE! button if you have to)  This shows confidence + gives the other person time to respond.   𝟰/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝟭-𝟮 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  We all lose deals.  It happens...   But those people know people who know people.  For every 1 deal you lose, ask for 2 referrals.   Referrals = Big $$$   𝟱/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 "𝗬𝗲𝘀, 𝗔𝗡𝗗" 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  “Yes, AND” is the antithesis of “Yes,  BUT”   Let’s compare:  Prospect: “It’s too expensive.”  🔴 “Yes, *BUT* the ROI is so worth it" 🟢 “Yes, *AND* will price keep you from getting what you really want?”  Different energy right?   𝟲/ 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗼-𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘆  Instead of trying to get people to say YES...   Focus on getting them to say NO.  People hate YES.  People love NO.  Examples:  • “Is now a bad time to talk?” • “Is it a ridiculous idea ... ?” • “Have you given up on … ?”  Thanks Chris Voss! Author: Andrew Mewborn
Post Text: If you use it right, storytelling is the #1 skill to make more sales. But 99% of the gurus do a terrible job of teaching you how to tell a story. Here's how to tell a story in 7 quick bullets:    "The most powerful person is the storyteller" -Steve Jobs  I never understood why.   Until..   I joined improv comedy.  4 years of improv later, I learned storytelling is the key to unlocking growth in:  • Writing • Business • Relationships  Here's the 7-sentence breakdown:   𝟭/ 𝗢𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘂𝗽𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 ____  This sentence is the INTRODUCTION.   It should introduce the setting and main character(s) of the story.   And...  Provide any necessary background information.   It should also establish the tone and mood of the story.   𝟮/ 𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗱𝗮𝘆 ____  This is the RISING ACTION.   The rising action presents the conflict or problem that the character(s) must face.   This sentence should introduce the stakes of the story.   And set the character(s) on their journey to resolve the conflict.   𝟯/ 𝗨𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗹 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗱𝗮𝘆 ____  This is the CLIMAX.   The climax is the point of highest tension or drama in the story.   It is the turning point that determines the outcome of the conflict.   This sentence should describe the event or decision that drives the story toward its resolution.   𝟰/ 𝗕𝗲𝗰𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 ____  This is the FALLING ACTION.   It consists of the events that follow the climax and lead to the resolution of the conflict.   This sentence should describe the character(s)' efforts to resolve the conflict and the challenges they face along the way.   𝟱/ 𝗕𝗲𝗰𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 ____  The RESOLUTION.  This is the end of the story, where the conflict is resolved and the character(s) achieve their goal(s).   This should describe the final outcome of the story...    And how the character(s) have changed as a result of their experiences.   𝟲/ 𝗨𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗹 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 ____  This is the CONCLUSION.  The conclusion is a summary of the events of the story and the lessons learned by the character(s).   This sentence should reflect on the significance of the story and its themes.   𝟳/ 𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗮𝘆 ____  The closing is a final thought or reflection on the story.   This sentence can be used to tie up any loose ends or provide a final:   • Lesson • Takeaway • Or epiphany   for the reader.   𝗡𝗼𝘄 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗳𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗸𝘀:  Once upon a time _____ And every day _____ Until one day _____ Because of this _____ Because of that _____ Until finally _____ And ever since that day _____  Viola! You've told a great story using just 7-sentences.   P.S. The waitlist for our 4,000+ member LinkedIn Growth Accelerator is now open: https://www.brand30.io/

Author: Andrew Mewborn
Post Text: How to close $100,000+ ARR customers.  (The 6-step Multi-Threading Method)  ↓  But hold up, Any. What is a multi-threaded deal?  The concept is simple.  We all know it:  9 out of 10 times you have to pull in multiple stakeholders to get a deal across the line.  No $100k+ deal gets done with one stakeholder involved.  (that's called a Unicorn deal)  ↓  Why multi-thread?  Your bigger deals ain’t going to get done without it.  Think about your own company when someone is trying to sell a product to YOUR team.  Does a salesperson get that done knowing one person?  No? Exactly.  Enough of the fluff, let’s get into the tactics.  ↓  𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟭: 𝗗𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗵𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸  You can spend hours researching a company.  Here’s what is most useful from a multi-threading perspective:  • What does the company do? • What other stakeholders should be involved? • Who are the company’s competitors? (are they customers of yours?  For small deals, this could take 5-10 minutes.  For larger deals, count on hours.   𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟮: 𝗦𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗮.  Make it about them.   Not you.    𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟯: 𝗨𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗱𝘂𝗮𝗹  Use this blurb to frame your question:  “I work with many who typically focus on X and Y to lead the agenda. Now I’m curious, what are your top two priorities as [persona]?”   𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟰: 𝗨𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁  After you get through the individual priorities, ask something along the lines of:  "Typically i see the top two priorities of <department> being A and B. Do these resonate?"   𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟱: 𝗚𝗲𝘁 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘁𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀  Sales reps love speaking to “how-to” tactical items.  If you start off on this front, Lily the VP is going to push you off to Henry the Manager.  Only get into tactics once you understand (you guessed it) the prospect’s priorities.   𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟲: 𝗔𝘀𝗸 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗽𝘀  This is where your multi-threading journey REALLY begins.  You are the expert. You know how deals get done. You know who is typically involved.  And in STEP 1 you did your homework (right?), so you already know the other potential stakeholders are.   Without understanding:  • The priorities of the individual you are speaking to • The priorities of the department they work in • What they are doing today  You are going to have a hard time getting to other stakeholders.  I’ll say it again: priorities, priorities, priorities.   Take the time to understand whether your solution solves a problem that is Priority #58 or Priority #10 for your prospects.  If you are priority #10, you’re doing pretty good.  If you are priority #1, that's even better.

Post Text: In 2015, I joined a startup making $18/hr. 7 years later I helped it go from $1M to $250M, started a side hustle that got to $1M ARR in 9 months (sold it for 8 figs), and just raised $2M to build out Distribute. Here's 10 super-quick lessons I've learned along the way:   1. Avoid the quick and easy paths.   Shortcuts rarely work out long-term.   And when they do, you can often get away with them for a while.   But eventually, the consequences catch up to you and it’s rarely worth it.   Shortcuts are longer roads in disguise.   2. Enjoy the adventure, and avoid obsessing over the outcome.  Focus on the journey, not the destination.   Enjoy the process and be present in each moment.   The outcome will take care of itself if you put in the work.   And at the end of the day, you'll always learn new lessons.   3. Be long-term greedy.  Help as many people as you can in the short term.   That way in the long term you can ask people for what you want, whenever you want.   4. Strong opinions, loosely held.  Listen to others, be open-minded, and think critically.   Forming a strong opinion or having conviction doesn’t have to mean being stubborn about it.   Be flexible and willing to change your mind if needed.   5. Make decisions faster than you’d like.  It's easy to second-guess yourself when making decisions.   But the longer you take to decision, the more time and energy you are wasting.   Make decisions faster than you’d like and don’t look back with regret.   6. Don't be realistic.   All too often, we set unrealistic expectations and then get frustrated when we don't reach them.   Instead of setting realistic goals, set ambitious ones.   Believe in yourself and go after the impossible.   7. Stay humble and be kind to others.   Humility is important for growth; it will open up opportunities that may never have crossed your path.   And no matter what, always be kind to others.   Even if they don’t deserve it, you will always benefit from being kind.   8. Simplify everything in life.  Simplicity brings clarity and focus to any task or project.   It can also help alleviate stress and anxiety.   Try to simplify everything you do, from decision-making to living arrangements to your inbox.   9. Don't be afraid to fail.  Fear of failure is the enemy of progress.   We learn more from our mistakes than we do from our successes, so don’t be afraid to take risks and make mistakes.   It's part of the process.   10. Don't take yourself too seriously.   At the end of the day, life is a journey and it should be enjoyed.   Have fun, laugh at yourself, and don’t take things too seriously.   Life is meant to be lived.  P.S.
